awd_titl_txt: SHF:Small:A Language-based Approach to Faster and Safer Serverless Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Cloud computing, which allows a customer to rent virtual servers from cloud providers, is the infrastructure that powers a wide variety of Internet applications used by consumers, businesses, and the government. Unfortunately, traditional cloud computing requires significant system-management expertise to ensure that applications are reliable, secure, and cost-effective. In contrast, "serverless computing" is a new approach to cloud computing that automates a significant portion of system management, and has seen explosive growth over the last few years. Despite being a promising advance, serverless computing introduces new problems, and is more limited in scope than traditional cloud computing. This research project develops tools and techniques to make serverless computing more cost-effective, more reliable, and more broadly applicable. 

The intellectual merits of the project are the development of (1) the mathematical foundations of serverless computing, (2) analysis tools to help programmers find and eliminate software bugs in serverless software, (3) new abstractions that enable a broader class of software to use serverless computing, and (4) new runtime systems that make serverless computing faster and cheaper. The project's broader significance and importance are that (1) it helps programmers make their serverless applications more reliable and secure, (2) it benefits cloud-computing providers by making serverless computing cheaper and faster, and (3) it encourages further research in this new area by enabling the publishing of research results and the release of open-source software. The project also involves high-school outreach workshops to broaden participation in computing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Serverless computing is a recent approach to cloud computing that allows programmers to run event-driven functions in the cloud, without the need to explicitly manage resource allocation. During the course of this project, we developed several fundamental technologies centered on programming languages used in serverless computing.

The first contribution of this project was research and development related to WebAssembly, which is a language and runtime system standard that is widely used behind the scenes for both web programming and serverless computing. For this project, we conducted fundamental research on WebAssembly effect handlers, which allow WebAssembly programs to express asynchronous tasks that commonly occur in serverless computing. The project started with fundamental research on WebAssembly continuations, which are a building block for effect handlers. We then proceeded to contribute to and build a prototype of WasmFX, which is a draft standard for WebAssembly effect handlers. The broader impact of our work is an ongoing standardization effort for WasmFX as well as prototypes of WasmFX in other WebAssembly implementations. 

The second contribution of this project was an investigation of the JavaScript software supply chain. (JavaScript is the most widely used programming language for serverless computing.) We developed a new package dependency solver for NPM, which is the de facto standard JavaScript package manager. We showed that this dependency solver can help optimize JavaScript application sizes, find solutions with newer package versions, and find solutions that avoid known bugs. We also conducted the largest scale empirical study of the more than two million publicly available NPM packages. This investigation revealed several features of how software updates, including security updates, propagate through the JavaScript software supply chain.

Finally, this project made key contributions to recent developments in large language models trained on code (Code LLMs). Specifically, the PI and his students led the evaluation and contributed to the data curation for SantaCoder and StarCoder, two open source Code LLMs that were state-of-the-art for their size when they were released. With our direction, these Code LLMs had multi-language evaluations that were far more comprehensive than prior work. This work had broader impact: these LLMs are widely used in both research and practice.

Modified by: Arjun Guha
